We also conduct a number of exploratory experiments to find out how pFedPT works and verify the effectiveness of pFedPT in terms of client data distribution. The detailed experimental setup and the more experimental results can be found in the Appendix.

A1.T3.caption: Table 3: The similarity between predicted and real data distribution
A1.T3.table:
Datasets Training Data Test Data Class Size
CIFAR-10 50,000 10,000 10 3×32×32332323\times 32\times 32
CIFAR-100 50,000 10,000 100 3×32×32332323\times 32\times 32
TinyImageNet 100,000 10,000 200 3×64×64364643\times 64\times 64
references: We adopt real-world datasets for the image classification task, including CIFAR10, CIFAR100, and Tiny ImageNet. The CIFAR10 dataset contains 50,000 training data and 10,000 test data in 10 classes. Each data sample is a 3×32×32332323\times 32\times 32 color image. CIFAR100 [25] includes 50,000 training data and 10,000 test data in 100 classes as 500 training samples per class. TinyImageNet [36] involves 100,000 training images and 10,000 test images in 200 classes for 3×64×64364643\times 64\times 64 color images, as shown in Table 3. For CIFAR10/100 and TinyImageNet, we normalize the pixel value within a specific mean and std value in our code, which are [0.5, 0.5, 0.5] for the mean and [0.5, 0.5, 0.5] for the std.

references: We compare the performance of pFedPT and other baselines on the TinyImageNet dataset with 500 rounds of communications. Tab.
shows that the experimental results in TinyImageNet are still consistent with the interpretation in Sec.

. For Pathological distribution with ViT, the test accuracy of the pFedPT is 25.95%, the accuracy of FedAvg achieves 9.37% and the accuracy of the FedPer achieves 19.23%. However, the test accuracy of the pFedPT is not the highest in Dirichlet distribution, our explanation is that it is hard to generate stable prompts in 500 rounds due to the increased task difficulty.
